items.title: JavaScript, ML and LLMs
items.content:
#â€‹654 â€” September 14, 2023

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Bun 1.0: Is It a Toolkit? Is It a Runtime? It's Both â€” Youâ€™ve used Node, youâ€™ve seen Deno, now Bun has grown up too. Itâ€™s a performance-oriented server-side JS runtime built atop JavaScriptCore and makes the unique claim of being â€œa drop-in replacement for Node.js.â€ It includes extras like transpilation, bundling, package management, and a Jest-compatible test runner too. The post goes into a lot of depth, but we enjoyed the Bun teamâ€™s â–¶ï¸ 10 minute introductory video. Does Bun deliver on all its promises yet? No. Is it promising? Yes.

Jarred Sumner et al.

Why Does every() Return true for Empty Arrays? â€” Nicholas wondered how a condition can possibly be satisfied when there arenâ€™t any values to test, so he dug into the language specs to understand theÂ logic.

Nicholas C. Zakas

The Complete UI Component Library For Enterprise Web Apps â€” A professional UI component library with power widgets like data grid, calendar, scheduler & Gantt charts. Includes API docs, guides and an unreasonable amount of demos to play with. Seamlessly integrates with React, Angular, Vue & SalesforceÂ apps.

Bryntum sponsor

A First Look at TypeScript 5.3 â€” TypeScript 5.2 landed a few weeks ago, which means TypeScript 5.3 is already in the works (the final release is due in November), with possible features to think about including Import Attributes, throw expressions, and isolatedÂ declarations.

Matt Pocock

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ“… ViteConf is taking place this October 5-6. It's free and online.

  • The August 2023 build of VS Code has just been released and includes improvements to the JS debugger including WebAssembly module decompilation, as well as Move to File and Inline Variable refactorings.

  • Linus Groh is working on a JavaScript engine in Zig called Kiesel, mostly as a learning project, but it's passing 25% of test262 after four months of effort.

  • While searching for something else, I encountered this JavaScript tutorial from 1996 that's still online. Amazingly, most of it still works fine today.

  • Esteemed Microsoft code archaeologist Raymond Chen looks at how freestanding JS functions using this can be mistaken for a constructor by VS Codeâ€™s static analyzer.

ğŸ‰ RELEASES:

  • MikroORM 5.8 â€“ Powerful Node.js ORM.

  • Reason 3.10 â€“ Write code in OCaml, but for the JS ecosystem.

  • Happy DOM 11.0 â€“ A JS implementation of a web browser sans UI.

  • Node.js v20.6.1 (Current)

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

JavaScript's New Array Grouping Methods â€” A look at Object.groupBy and Map.groupBy. The proposal including these methods is currently at stage 3 at TC39, but initial support is creeping into dev builds of browsers.

Phil Nash

JPEG and EXIF Data Manipulation in JavaScript â€” A look at how to pick through the JPEG format and read and replace EXIF tags directly without leaning on a third partyÂ library.

CÃ©dric Patchane

Frontend Performance Monitoring 101 â€” Learn the basics of JavaScript application performance monitoring to see (and fix) slow faster. Join us for aÂ liveÂ AMA.

Sentry sponsor

â–¶Â Â Building a Mario Game Complete with Auth and Score Saving â€” Ania tackles the implementation of a game in her usual thorough, step-by-stepÂ manner.

Ania KubÃ³w

Running a Playwright Script on AWS Lambda â€” If youâ€™ve struggled to make it work too, Matt has someÂ pointers.

Matt Steele

A New Method to Validate URLs â€” URL.canParse isnâ€™t broadly supported yet, but can be easilyÂ polyfilled.

Stefan Judis

How to Run a GitHub Gist with npx â€” This is an interesting way to quickly deploy a script.

Kelly Fox

ğŸ•‘ Lei Mao has a cute example of using React in an ad-hoc way on a web page to dynamically render an analog clock. No build step. No JSX.

â–¶ï¸ Jack Herrington refutes six reasons not to use React.

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Shadcn for Vue: Components You Can Copy and Paste â€” A community-led Vue port of the React-oriented shadcn/ui, a suite of attractive components built with Tailwind CSS and Radix UI, thus making them easy to â€˜copy and pasteâ€™ into your ownÂ apps.

Radix Vue Project

FlexGrid by Wijmo: The Industry-Leading JavaScript Datagrid

Wijmo from GrapeCity sponsor

npm-check-updates: Update package.json Dependencies to LatestÂ Versions â€” That is, as opposed to the specified versions. It include a handy -i interactive mode so you can look at potential upgrades and then opt in to them one byÂ one.

Raine Revere

Starry Night 3.0: GitHub-Like Syntax Highlighting â€” GitHubâ€™s own syntax highlighter isnâ€™t open source, but Starry Night uses WebAssembly (to get access to the Oniguruma regex engine) to get as close as itÂ can.

Titus Wormer

Vuestic 1.8: Open Source UI Library for Vue 3 â€” A library of more than 60 customizable components. v1.8 introduces new Layout and Textarea components. OfficialÂ homepage.

Epicmax

Goxygen 0.7: Quickly Generate a Go Backend for a JS Project â€” A tool that sets up a new Go-based project with Angular, React, or Vue in the front-end, and Docker and Docker Compose files to make it allÂ work.

Sasha Shpota

Deliver Real-Time Live Streams with Amazon IVS â€” Amazon IVS enables developers to create dynamic real-time and low-latency video experiences. ClickÂ here to learnÂ more.

Amazon Web Services (AWS) sponsor

xterm.js 5.3.0: Build Terminals in the Browser â€” Itâ€™s used in many projects like VS Code, cPanel, Azure Cloud Shell, and other browser-based IDEs. Thereâ€™s a live demo on the homepage toÂ try.

xterm.js team

  • Gridstack.js 9.2
    â†³ Build interactive dashboards in minutes. (Demos.)

  • Accessible Astro Starter 3.0
    â†³ A starter theme for an Astro-powered blog.

  • Ant Design 5.9
    â†³ Popular React UI library & design language.

  • ğŸ“Š Reveal.js 4.6 â€“ Write presentations in HTML.

  • Electron 26.2

ğŸ’» Jobs

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
Hired

ğŸ¤–Â A little JavaScript AI-side..

AI, LLMs and machine learning have caught the imagination of many developers recently, whether through training and deploying models, calling out to third party APIs (like those OpenAI offers), or using tools like GitHub Copilot to write code. It's common, however, for a lot of AI/LLM experimentation to take place in Python, rather than JavaScript..

Nonetheless, there's an increasing number of projects in the JavaScript AI/ML space worth keeping an eye on, as well as an upcoming AI developer event being organized by two folks from the JavaScript space:

Transformers.js: State-of-the-Art Machine Learning for the Web â€” A JavaScript library designed to be functionally equivalent to Hugging Faceâ€™s transformers Python library meaning you can run the same pretrained models using a very similar API. You can do things like ML-powered speech recognition directly in your browser using OpenAIâ€™s Whisper model. GitHubÂ repo.

Joshua Lochner et al.

Microsoft TypeChat: An Approach for Type-Safe LLM Responses â€” Anders Hejlsberg and Daniel Rosenwasser of TypeScript fame are just two of the prominent names attached to this project, demonstrating the huge interest within MS for LLMs. TypeChatâ€™s goal is to work around the issue of LLMs outputting unstructured natural language and to direct output into a typed form.

Hejlsberg, Lucco, Rosenwasser et al.

WebLLM: Run LLM Models in the Browser with WebGPU â€” Less directly JavaScript, as it uses WebGPU, but yet another way to run large language models directly within the browser and that you can control from JavaScript. GitHubÂ repo.

MLC LLM

TensorFlow.js: Machine Learning for JavaScript Developers â€” Slightly lower level, but a great way to train and deploy models in the browser or in Node.js. There are, of course, lots of demos, too.

TensorFlow

JavaScript Library Lets Devs Add AI Capabilities to the Web
Loraine Lawson (The New Stack)

â–¶Â Â A Primer on AI for Developers with Swyx from Latent Space
Svelte Radio

ğŸ“… Plus, two JavaScript folks are putting on an AI event..

As part of my interest in AI and ML, I'm attending what promises to be the technical AI event of the year in San Francisco next month: The AI EngineerÂ Summit.

The emerging 'AI engineer' category is at the intersection of AI/ML and code: where software engineers can access and implement powerful AI models with just an API. Andrej Karpathy believes that "there's probably going to be significantly more AI engineers than there are ML engineers / LLM engineers."

With speakers representing companies like OpenAI, Microsoft, Replit, Vercel, AutoGPT, Adept, LlamaIndex, and Notion, at the Hotel Nikko this October 8-10, the event is organized by two folks well known in our space: Swyx (who you may remember from his popular The Third Age of JavaScript post) and Benjamin Dunphy, formerly of Reactathon and Jamstack Conf. You can apply to attend or get a free remote ticket to tune in from wherever you are.

If you're going to the AI Engineer Summit, I'll see you there!

ğŸ‘‹

items.title: TypeScript 5.2, Node 20.6, and Astro 3.0
items.content:
#â€‹653 â€” September 7, 2023

Read on the Web

ğŸ˜… We're back! After two weeks enjoying the blistering desert heat of Las Vegas and downpours of Storm Hilary, I'm ready to get back to the weekly JavaScript roundups â€“Â fingers crossed we're here each week till Christmas now :-)
__
Peter Cooper and the Cooperpress team

JavaScript Weekly

Astro 3.0 Released: The All-in-One Web Framework â€” An increasingly popular, turbo-charged site generator comfortable with not just static sites, but dynamic and interactive ones too by way of its â€˜islandsâ€™ approach. You can use React, Vue, Svelte, Solid, and others, with it, and v3 adds View Transitions API support (more on that here) which can result in striking creations like this Spotify 'clone'. It requires a play to really 'get it' but it'sÂ great.

Astro Team

Good news â€“ now SvelteKit supports the View Transitions API too ğŸ˜‰

Node.js 20.6 Released with Built-In Support for .env Files â€” The official release post covers everything new in 20.6, but the highlight is support for .env environment files to set environment variables dynamically when a script is run without requiring a third-party library like dotenv.

Phil Nash

Simplify Security and Compliance for Your Apps â€” Introducing Pangea: comprehensive API-based security services for developers. Effortlessly integrate foundational security services like Authentication, Authorization, and Audit Logging to create a safer app experience and accelerate your timeÂ toÂ market.

Pangea sponsor

Bye to Rome and Hi to Biome for JS Formatting and Linting â€” First announced in 2020, Rome is/was an ambitious effort to create a unified frontend dev tool to bring ideas from Babel, ESLint, webpack, etc. into one place. After forming a company around Rome and raising money two years ago, things seem to have gone awry, with its key maintainers forking the project as Biome.

Emanuele Stoppa and the Biome Team

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF:

  • Version 1.0 of Bun, the notably fast JavaScriptCore-based JS runtime, is due to launch in the coming hours. There's a livestream and, we assume, a launch post due to land here very soon.

  • In other 'alternative runtime news', the Deno team has announced native npm support on its Deno Deploy platform. They've also announced Deno KV is in open beta.

  • Mozilla: "Over the course of the year Firefox has improved by around 40% on the Vue.js benchmark" â€“ find out why.

  • David Heinemeier Hansson, the creator of Ruby on Rails, announced that they're dropping TypeScript from Turbo (a library commonly used with Rails) in favor of plain old JavaScript. Social media drama ensued.

  • What's going on with the Gatsby React framework? Folks are noticing there's not a lot going on with it lately and that ğŸ¦ Netlify layoffs had a big impact. Netlify does, however, say ğŸ¦ updates are coming.

  • GitHub has made changes to its homepage feeds. Quite a few people are unhappy about it, though.

  • "The CSS-in-JS sector has plateaued," says the latest State of CSS survey.

  • What's new in Svelte as of September 2023? Quite aÂ lot.

ğŸ‰ RELEASES:

  • TypeScript 5.2 â€“ Complete with the much awaited using declarations..

  • Node-RED 3.1 â€“ The powerful low-code/visual programming environment gets some key improvements in its editor.

  • jq 1.7 â€“ It's not JavaScript, but surely the best JSON processing tool to exist.

  • Ky 1.0 â€“ Simple HTTP client based upon Fetch for browsers, NodeÂ &Â Deno.

  • jQuery 3.7.1 â€“ Oh yes indeedy ğŸ‰

  • Cypress 13

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Making Sense of React Server Components â€” This is fantastic and exactly what it says on the tin, â€“ we'll be focusing on it more in next week's React Status newsletter thoughÂ ğŸ˜‰

Josh W Comeau

You Don't Need to Learn Svelte â€“ Here's Why â€” I mean.. you kinda do, but Kaviiâ€™s excitement is infectious and Svelteâ€™s approach remainsÂ refreshing.

Kavii Suri

item:Â Using Labeled Loops in JavaScript â€” If using labels gives you flashbacks to BASIC and GOTO statements, I sympathize, but in JavaScript, labels open up an interesting control flowÂ technique. More about this on MDN. continueÂ item;

Ben Nadel

Build a Documentation Chatbot with ChatGPT and EdgeDB â€” Let's do it using EdgeDB's intuitive data model & query language, as well as its powerful TypeScript queryÂ builder.

EdgeDB sponsor

A Wide View of Automated Testing in React Apps â€” A straightforward and to the point introduction to why you might use automated testing, how to get going in the scope of a React app, and what to beÂ testing.

The React Handbook

How to Create a Dual-Mode Cross-Runtime JavaScript Package â€” Specifically, supporting both ESM and CommonJS, and across runtimes like Node, Deno and theÂ browser.

Hexagon

Benchmarking 24 CSV Parsing Approaches â€” The most extensive CSV parsing benchmark Iâ€™ve seen. The author is himself the creator of the Î¼DSV CSV parsing library and wanted to check out the common â€˜lightning fast performanceâ€™ claims of otherÂ libaries.

Leon Sorokin

The Complexity of Building an Efficient Node.js Docker Image â€” Itâ€™s possible to get huge reductions in image size and build time and Samuel shares his approach here, but he also questions whether all this work should beÂ necessary.

Samuel Bodin

Learn High-Level Compilers, Tools, & Techniques â€“ in JavaScript!

Dmitry Soshnikov Education sponsor

14 Linting Rules To Help You Write Asynchronous JS Code
Maxim Orlov

How to Create a Chrome Extension in 10 Minutes Flat
James Hibbard

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Peaks.js 3.0: View and Interact with Audio Waveforms â€” A JavaScript component for browser-based audio waveform visualization that comes from the BBCâ€™s R&D department. Thereâ€™s a live example on the homepage. GitHubÂ repo.

BBC

ğŸ¸Â SVGuitar: Create SVG-Based Guitar Chord Charts â€” Why not continue with the musical theme? ğŸ˜ You can experiment with this one via this liveÂ demo.

Raphael Voellmy

FormKit 1.0: The Open-Source Form Framework for Vue â€” Ships with production-ready scaffolding like inputs, forms, submission and error handling, and validationÂ rules.

FormKit, Inc.

Add Authorization, MFA, Biometrics and More to Your JavaScript App in Just Minutes â€” It's about time that somebody talked some sense about OAuth and JavaScript. So we did. You'reÂ welcome.

FusionAuth sponsor

Plate: Roll Your Own Slate-Based Rich-Text Editor â€” A framework for building React-based rich text editors where you can select the specific features and functionality you need. GitHubÂ repo.

Ziad Beyens

Math.js: An Extensive Math Library for Node and Browser â€” Work with complex numbers, fractions, units, matrices, symbolic computation, etc. A long standing library now, but continuing to get frequent updates. GitHubÂ repo.

Jos de Jong

Calendar.js: A Calendar Control with Drag and Drop â€” A responsive calendar with no dependencies, full drag and drop support (even between calendars) and many ways to manage events with recurring events, exporting, holidays, andÂ more.

William Troup

ğŸ’» Jobs

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
Hired

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» Got a job listing to share? Here's how.

  • npm-to-yarn â€“ Convert npm commands to yarn and vice versa.

  • export-to-csv - Export arrays of objects to CSV.

  • Marked 8.0 â€“ Fast Markdown parsing library. (Demo.)

  • Perfectionist 2.0 â€“ ESLint plugin for sorting various data.

  • React Native Vision Camera 3.0
    â†³ Powerful camera control for React Native apps.

  • YouTube.js 6.3
    â†³ Client library for YouTube's internal API.

  • Ink 4.4 â€“ Use React to build CLI apps.

  • Prisma 5.2

  • ffmpeg.wasm 0.12.6

Mozilla: "Over the course of the year Firefox has improved by around 40% on the Vue.js benchmark" â€“ find out why.
David Heinemeier Hansson, the creator of Ruby on Rails, announced that they're dropping TypeScript from Turbo (a library commonly used with Rails) in favor of plain old JavaScript. Social media drama ensued.
What's going on with the Gatsby React framework? Folks are noticing there's not a lot going on with it lately and that ğŸ¦ Netlify layoffs had a big impact. Netlify does, however, say ğŸ¦ updates are coming.
GitHub has made changes to its homepage feeds. Quite a few people are unhappy about it, though.
"The CSS-in-JS sector has plateaued," says the latest State of CSS survey.
What's new in Svelte as of September 2023? Quite aÂ lot.


ğŸ‰ RELEASES:
TypeScript 5.2 â€“ Complete with the much awaited using declarations..
Node-RED 3.1 â€“ The powerful low-code/visual programming environment gets some key improvements in its editor.
jq 1.7 â€“ It's not JavaScript, but surely the best JSON processing tool to exist.
Ky 1.0 â€“ Simple HTTP client based upon Fetch for browsers, NodeÂ &Â Deno.
jQuery 3.7.1 â€“ Oh yes indeedy ğŸ‰
Cypress 13


ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials





  
  
Making Sense of React Server Components â€” This is fantastic and exactly what it says on the tin, â€“ we'll be focusing on it more in next week's React Status newsletter thoughÂ ğŸ˜‰
Josh W Comeau 


  
  
You Don't Need to Learn Svelte â€“ Here's Why â€” I mean.. you kinda do, but Kaviiâ€™s excitement is infectious and Svelteâ€™s approach remainsÂ refreshing.
Kavii Suri 


  
  
item:Â Using Labeled Loops in JavaScript â€” If using labels gives you flashbacks to BASIC and GOTO statements, I sympathize, but in JavaScript, labels open up an interesting control flowÂ technique. More about this on MDN. continueÂ item;
Ben Nadel 


  
  
Build a Documentation Chatbot with ChatGPT and EdgeDB â€” Let's do it using EdgeDB's intuitive data model & query language, as well as its powerful TypeScript queryÂ builder.
EdgeDB sponsor


  
  
A Wide View of Automated Testing in React Apps â€” A straightforward and to the point introduction to why you might use automated testing, how to get going in the scope of a React app, and what to beÂ testing.
The React Handbook 


  
  
How to Create a Dual-Mode Cross-Runtime JavaScript Package â€” Specifically, supporting both ESM and CommonJS, and across runtimes like Node, Deno and theÂ browser.
Hexagon 


  
  
Benchmarking 24 CSV Parsing Approaches â€” The most extensive CSV parsing benchmark Iâ€™ve seen. The author is himself the creator of the Î¼DSV CSV parsing library and wanted to check out the common â€˜lightning fast performanceâ€™ claims of otherÂ libaries.
Leon Sorokin 


  
  
The Complexity of Building an Efficient Node.js Docker Image â€” Itâ€™s possible to get huge reductions in image size and build time and Samuel shares his approach here, but he also questions whether all this work should beÂ necessary.
Samuel Bodin 


  
  
Learn High-Level Compilers, Tools, & Techniques â€“ in JavaScript!
Dmitry Soshnikov Education sponsor


  
14 Linting Rules To Help You Write Asynchronous JS Code
  
Maxim Orlov 
  


  
How to Create a Chrome Extension in 10 Minutes Flat
  
James Hibbard 
  


ğŸ› Â Code & Tools 




  





  
  
Peaks.js 3.0: View and Interact with Audio Waveforms â€” A JavaScript component for browser-based audio waveform visualization that comes from the BBCâ€™s R&D department. Thereâ€™s a live example on the homepage. GitHubÂ repo.
BBC 


  
  
ğŸ¸Â SVGuitar: Create SVG-Based Guitar Chord Charts â€” Why not continue with the musical theme? ğŸ˜ You can experiment with this one via this liveÂ demo.
Raphael Voellmy 


  
  
FormKit 1.0: The Open-Source Form Framework for Vue â€” Ships with production-ready scaffolding like inputs, forms, submission and error handling, and validationÂ rules.
FormKit, Inc. 


  
  
Add Authorization, MFA, Biometrics and More to Your JavaScript App in Just Minutes â€” It's about time that somebody talked some sense about OAuth and JavaScript. So we did. You'reÂ welcome.
FusionAuth sponsor


  
  
Plate: Roll Your Own Slate-Based Rich-Text Editor â€” A framework for building React-based rich text editors where you can select the specific features and functionality you need. GitHubÂ repo.
Ziad Beyens 


  
  
Math.js: An Extensive Math Library for Node and Browser â€” Work with complex numbers, fractions, units, matrices, symbolic computation, etc. A long standing library now, but continuing to get frequent updates. GitHubÂ repo.
Jos de Jong 


  
  
Calendar.js: A Calendar Control with Drag and Drop â€” A responsive calendar with no dependencies, full drag and drop support (even between calendars) and many ways to manage events with recurring events, exporting, holidays, andÂ more.
William Troup 





ğŸ’» Jobs





  
Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
  
Hired 
  


ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» Got a job listing to share? Here's how.














npm-to-yarn â€“ Convert npm commands to yarn and vice versa.
export-to-csv - Export arrays of objects to CSV.
Marked 8.0 â€“ Fast Markdown parsing library. (Demo.)
Perfectionist 2.0 â€“ ESLint plugin for sorting various data.
React Native Vision Camera 3.0
YouTube.js 6.3
Ink 4.4 â€“ Use React to build CLI apps.
Prisma 5.2
ffmpeg.wasm 0.12.6

items.title: We're taking a few weeks off, but..
items.content:
#â€‹652 â€” August 17, 2023

Read on the Web

ğŸï¸ I'm taking two weeks off and will be back on Thursday, September 7. So if you don't see the newsletter turn up for a while, it's our faultÂ ;-) As I've had to produce much of this issue a few days in advance, I'm mixing in some 'golden oldies' and popular items from earlier this year to keep things interesting, so this is a less newsy issue than usual. See you again inÂ September!Â ğŸ‘‹
__
Peter Cooper, your editor

JavaScript Weekly

How Dropbox Reduced the Size of Its JavaScript Bundles by 33% â€” The folks at Dropbox realize that when youâ€™re operating at scale, small annoyances and delays add up, and their web perf team narrowed down some of Dropboxâ€™s perf issues to their module bundlingÂ process.

Nadeem and Hong (Dropbox)

htmx is Part of the GitHub Accelerator â€” htmx is a perfect example of a library that isnâ€™t brand new, but one that becomes popular once the time is right. Its success is only continuing following acceptance into the first class of GitHubâ€™s open-source Accelerator initiative, an opportunity that will enable the development of htmx 2.0. GitHubÂ repo.

Big Sky Software

You Might Not Need a Framework â€” Maximiliano Firtman shares the vanilla approach in this video course on building rich web apps and sites without depending on libraries of frameworks. It covers the DOM, event handling, routing, web components, andÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

You Don't (May Not) Need Lodash or Underscore â€” Inspired by the popular You Might Not Need jQuery, this extensive document provides pure JavaScript alternatives to almost 100 different functions as youâ€™d find in popular utility libraries like Lodash.

You Don't Need

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF:

  • It's still a few weeks away, but we're told "Bun 1.0 is almost here" and there's ğŸ“… a live presentation by Bun's creator, Jarred Sumner, on September 7 you can sign up for now.

  • If you like to keep up with other languages than JavaScript, renowned C++ expert Herb Sutter recently â–¶ï¸ gave a fantastic talk about modernizing and improving C++ more quickly by creating a Typescript-esque superset with better abstractions and features.

  • ğŸ•¹ React Jam was a React-oriented gamejam that took place last week and here are the winning games.

  • ğŸ‘¾ Talking of gaming, the annual js13kGames JS coding competition has just started. You can join in the fun, though, as it doesn't end till September 13.

  • Robin Wieruch shared his 10 Web development trends in 2023 back in January â€“ how are they shaping up so far? As Larry David might say.. pretty, pretty good.

  • In "The â€œSkeleton Squadâ€ is now targeting NPM", the team at Socket take a look at how a group is attacking the npm package ecosystem.

  • ğŸ¦â–¶ï¸ Playing with the earliest JavaScript in Netscape 2.0.

ğŸ‰ RELEASES:

  • Fresh 1.4
    â†³ The Deno-powered web framework.

  • jest-dom 6.0
    â†³ Custom matchers to test the state of the DOM.

  • NodeBB 3.3 â€“ Node.js-powered forum software.

  • Electron 26.0

  • Angular 16.2

  • Playwright 1.37.0

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Discover three.js: A Complete Guide to Creating 3D Web Experiences â€” The breadth of the content on offer here had me looking for the price, but itâ€™s all online and free. Thereâ€™s a lot to dig through here if you want to get started (or just get better) at using three.js. If youâ€™re already familiar with three.js, you may enjoy the three.js tips and tricksÂ page.

Lewy Blue

JSX Without React â€” Exploring a new tool called NakedJSX that will allow you to render JSX without the need for the full ReactÂ framework.

Chris Coyier

React Authentication â€” Without Complexity â€” Userfront streamlines authentication & access control so engineers can focus on their core business. Read the docsÂ now.

Userfront sponsor

Youâ€™ve Got Options for Removing Event Listeners â€” Reviewing some of the most common approaches available to remove event listeners inÂ JavaScript.

Alex MacArthur

Prepare Your Firefox Desktop Extension for the Upcoming AndroidÂ Release â€” â€œFirefox will become the only major Android browser to support an open extensionÂ ecosystem.â€

Scott DeVaney (Mozilla)

Application State Management with Angular Signals
Yevgeny / Oz

â–¶Â Â Six (or so) New Approved and Proposed JavaScript APIs
Syntax Pocast podcast

The Importance of Verifying Webhook Signatures
Marcelo Oliveira (Snyk)

Writing JavaScript Without a Build System
Julia Evans

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Croner 7.0: Cron for JavaScript and TypeScript â€” Trigger functions upon the schedule of your choice using the classic cron syntax. Works in Node, Deno, Bun and the browser, across time zones, offers error handling and overrun protection, and more. Thereâ€™s an live demo on JSFiddle. v7.0 adds support for specifying the n-thÂ weekday.

Hexagon

Linkify 4.1: Link Up URLs, Email Addresses, and More in Plain Text â€” Given some plain text containing things like links and emails, Linkify will generate the correct code to display it on the Web. Not just URLs or emails, but hashtags, @mentions, IP addresses, and more â€“ see the homepage for examples. GitHubÂ repo.

Hypercontext

ğŸ¦˜JavaScript Scratchpad for VS Code: New Logpoints Feature! â€” Seeing runtime values has never been so easy. Simply place a breakpoint on a line, no debugger required: zeroÂ setup/configuration.

Wallaby.js sponsor

deno_python: Python Interpreter Bindings for Deno â€” A seamless Deno-Python integration via the Python/C API. The latest release supports installing and importing pip packages. This feature has been described as â€œslightly cursedâ€ but itâ€™s certainlyÂ interesting.

Denosaurs

Tagger: A Zero Dependency, Vanilla JavaScript Tagging Library â€” You can play with a live demoÂ here.

Jakub T. Jankiewicz

Over 100 Algorithms and Data Structures Demonstrated in JS â€” Examples of many common algorithms (e.g. bit manipulation, Pascalâ€™s triangle, Hamming distance) and data structures (e.g. linked lists, tries, graphs) with explanations. Available in other languages too like Chinese, Korean, French, andÂ Spanish.

Oleksii Trekhleb et al.

Deliver Interactive Real-Time Live Streams with Amazon IVS

Amazon Web Services (AWS) sponsor

Proto Tree: A Way to Observe the JS Prototype Chain â€” Gal explains the motivation for this tool in ğŸ¦ this TwitterÂ thread.

Gal Weizman

Barba.js: For Smooth Visual Transitions Between Pages â€” You certainly canâ€™t say the projectâ€™s homepage doesnâ€™t show off all of its features. For such a dramatic set of effects, things feel smooth and surprisingly nice ğŸ˜ GitHubÂ repo.

De Rosa, Michel, et al.

Stritch: A JavaScript Barcode Scanning Library â€” Itâ€™s a commercial library, but featureful and well presented with support for a variety of 1D and 2D barcodeÂ types.

Pixelverse LLC

#Script: A JS-Inspired Scripting Language for .NET â€” An embeddable scripting language mostly targeting template use cases. It can also be used in a LispÂ style.

ServiceStack

ğŸ’» Jobs

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
Hired

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» Got a job listing to share? Here's how.

ngraph.path: Path Finding Through Graphs â€” Thereâ€™s a live demo if you want to see how it tackles the road network of several globalÂ cities.

Andrei Kashcha

  • SVGR 8.1
    â†³ Transform SVGs into React components.

  • BlockNote 0.9
    â†³ "Notion-style" block-based editor built atop Prosemirror. (Demo)

  • React Number Format 5.3
    â†³ Input formatter library for numbers.

  • Tinypool 0.8
    â†³ Minimal/tiny Node.js worker thread pool.

  • melonJS 15.9 â€“ Lightweight HTML5 game engine.

  • Sortable 2.3 â€“ Vanilla JS table sort. (Demo)

  • Preact 10.17.0

ğŸ˜­ Last week I promised a JavaScript AI/ML feature, but time hasn't worked out in my favor (note to self: don't send an issue while on vacation ğŸ˜†). Keep your fingers crossed and it'll be in one of the next issues. So much has been happening in the JavaScript AI/ML space that we want to shine a spotlight on it sooner than later.

ğŸ‘‹ We'll be back in three weeks on September 7, 2023. See you soon! If you have anything to submit for the next issue, hit reply and let us know (but appreciate we may be slow to reply since we'll be on vacation ğŸ˜‰).

items.title: Svelte 5 is going to be radical
items.content:
#â€‹651 â€” August 10, 2023

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

My Experience Modernizing Packages to ESM â€” What a post! Mark, well known for his work on React, Redux, and much more, details the painful experiences and hard-earned lessons he picked up while migrating the Redux packages toÂ ESÂ modules.

Mark 'acemarke' Erikson

Things You Forgot (or Never Knew) Because of React â€” â€œIâ€™ve written before about how React is the new default frontend framework, and how I donâ€™t think most people using React on a regular basis realize quite how much itâ€™s fallen behind.â€ High level thoughts about the React â€˜bubbleâ€™ and some reasons to look beyond it, including a round up of some of the alternativeÂ options.

Josh Collinsworth

Build Web Apps in 60 Seconds with DynaboardÂ AI â€” Dynaboard's low-code IDE offers 40+ built-in UI components. Quickly connect to REST & GraphQL APIs, SQL databases, and spreadsheets. Write custom code or use AI to generate any SQL, JS, orÂ CSS.

Dynaboard sponsor

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF:

  • "Svelte 5 is going to be radical," ğŸ¦ tweets Rich Harris.

  • Server side JS runtime Deno 1.36 has been released with extended security options, a polyfill for node:test, completion of the node:os polyfill, and many other minor Node.js compatibility improvements.

  • Google has unveiled a sneak peek of a new IDE it's developing called Project IDX. It has VS Code at its base but with strong JS framework support, simulators, and lot of 'AI smarts' on top, ğŸ¦ says Addy Osmani.

  • A revived but early stage proposal for introducing observables to JavaScript. Your feedback is sought, so file an issue if you have any.

  • A fun walk through front-end history with a blog post containing every HTML element (well, almost â€“ sorry applet).

  • Nim 2.0 has been released. Nim is a C++ and Python inspired, statically typed systems language, that supports being compiled to JavaScript.

ğŸ‰ RELEASES:

  • TypeScript 5.2 RC â€“ TS 5.2 is nearly set for its final release. Explicit resource management with using is the headline feature, but there's more, as usual.

  • esbuild 0.19.0 â€“ The high-perf bundler can now import paths containing wildcards and supports advanced CSS @import rules. Note that this release contains backwards-incompatible changes.

  • Astro 2.10 â€“ There's also a first beta of Astro 3.

  • Node.js Security Releases â€“ v20.5.1 (Current), v18.17.1 (LTS) and v16.20.2 (LTS) are all part of this set of releases including OpenSSL security updates and fixes, mostly, around permission policies.

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Bringing Sharp to WebAssembly and WebContainers â€” A look at how itâ€™s possible to bring Sharp, a popular Node.js image manipulation module, into the browser. Welcome to theÂ future.

Ingvar Stepanyan

A Compilation of Outstanding JS Testing Articles â€” An opinionated list of 10 outstanding testing articles, all with a JS slant to them. He also mentions his own list of JavaScript and Node.js Testing Best Practices which is worth revisitingÂ too.

Yoni Goldberg

ğŸš€ JavaScript Moves Fastâ€”and So Should You. Let Us Help YouÂ Upgrade â€” React, Vue, Next, Node - our expert devs have it covered! Technical debt mounting? We're your tech debt busters!Â ğŸ‘Š

Reduce Tech Debt. UpgradeJS now. sponsor

â–¶Â Â A Look at HTMX: A 'Game-Changing' Alternative to React? â€” One of Jackâ€™s typically well produced, short tours (just 14-minutes). He likes htmx and thinks itâ€™s worth learning in order to have more options in yourÂ toolbox.

Jack Herrington

ğŸ“ Prefer a traditional writeup? James Hibbard has one here.

Node.js's 'Config Hell' Problem â€” Andy ponders why a Next.js project has over 30 configuration files and what we can do to avoid it (unsurprisingly, it involves using Deno, but I enjoy theÂ boldness).

Andy Jiang (Deno)

Creating a Screen + Camera Recorder with the Document Picture-in-PictureÂ API â€” This is more powerful than I was expecting. You can basically record a screencast using browser APIs. In Chrome, atÂ least.

SÃ©bastien Jalliffier Verne

React Authentication â€” Without Complexity

Userfront sponsor

â–¶Â Â Build and Deploy a Full Stack MERN Next.js 13 Threads Clone â€” An extensive, five hour screencast walking through the creation of a Threads/Twitter/X-style app using Next.js 13 and Clerk for userÂ management.

Adrian Hajdin

â–¶Â Â Turbopack vs Webpack â€” Being involved with the development of both bundlers, Tobias Koppers has some interesting things to say about the differences and explains why Turbopack isÂ necessary.

Tobias Koppers and Jack Herrington

Autogenerating Rust-JS Bindings with UniFFI
Ben Dean-Kawamura (Mozilla)

Migrating My Blog from Gatsby to Astro
Artem Sapegin

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Fuite 3.0: A Tool for Finding Memory Leaks in Web Apps â€” A CLI tool that you can point at any URL to analyze for memory leaks. Introductory blog post here, and thereâ€™s also a videoÂ tutorial.

Nolan Lawson

Luxon 3.4: Date and Time Manipulation Library â€” If youâ€™re familiar with Moment.js, itâ€™s like that but with immutable objects, 1-indexed months, Intl-powered localization (so no locale or timezone files needed) andÂ more.

Moment.js

JavaScript Frontend Error Monitoring 101 â€” Take a crash (pun intended) course on frontend error monitoring with Sentry. ReadÂ on.

Sentry sponsor

Filesize.js: Generate Human Readable Strings From File Sizes â€” For example, 123456 bytes could turn into "120.56 KB" - though different standards of conversion can also be used. GitHubÂ repo.

Jason Mulligan

Typograms: A Way to Render ASCII Diagrams More Elegantly â€” An intriguing project where you â€˜drawâ€™ diagrams in plain ASCII text within special script tags and these get rendered into much nicer looking versions. An interesting approach if Mermaid is too full on for yourÂ needs.

Sam Goto / Google

ğŸ’¡ Talking of Mermaid, the latest release supports SankeyÂ diagrams.

d3-graphviz 5.1: Graphviz DOT Rendering and Animated Transitions â€” Renders SVGs from DOT-defined graphs using a WebAssembly port ofÂ Graphviz, a popular graph visualizationÂ tool.

Magnus Jacobsson

ğŸ”ŠÂ Meyda: Audio Feature Extraction Library â€” Supports both offline feature extraction as well as real-time feature extraction using the Web Audio API. You can play with a demo right on theÂ homepage.

Rawlinson, Segal, Fiala, Wray, et al.

Packages can be colored by various criteria (such as number of maintainers, if you want to see how fragile the world is) and you can download SVGs of theÂ output.

items.contentSnippet:
#â€‹651 â€” August 10, 2023


Read on the Web



JavaScript Weekly




  





  
  
My Experience Modernizing Packages to ESM â€” What a post! Mark, well known for his work on React, Redux, and much more, details the painful experiences and hard-earned lessons he picked up while migrating the Redux packages toÂ ESÂ modules.
Mark 'acemarke' Erikson 


  
  
Things You Forgot (or Never Knew) Because of React â€” â€œIâ€™ve written before about how React is the new default frontend framework, and how I donâ€™t think most people using React on a regular basis realize quite how much itâ€™s fallen behind.â€ High level thoughts about the React â€˜bubbleâ€™ and some reasons to look beyond it, including a round up of some of the alternativeÂ options.
Josh Collinsworth 


  
  
Build Web Apps in 60 Seconds with DynaboardÂ AI â€” Dynaboard's low-code IDE offers 40+ built-in UI components. Quickly connect to REST & GraphQL APIs, SQL databases, and spreadsheets. Write custom code or use AI to generate any SQL, JS, orÂ CSS.
Dynaboard sponsor


âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF:
"Svelte 5 is going to be radical," ğŸ¦ tweets Rich Harris.
Server side JS runtime Deno 1.36 has been released with extended security options, a polyfill for node:test, completion of the node:os polyfill, and many other minor Node.js compatibility improvements.
Google has unveiled a sneak peek of a new IDE it's developing called Project IDX. It has VS Code at its base but with strong JS framework support, simulators, and lot of 'AI smarts' on top, ğŸ¦ says Addy Osmani.
A revived but early stage proposal for introducing observables to JavaScript. Your feedback is sought, so file an issue if you have any.
A fun walk through front-end history with a blog post containing every HTML element (well, almost â€“ sorry applet).
Nim 2.0 has been released. Nim is a C++ and Python inspired, statically typed systems language, that supports being compiled to JavaScript.


ğŸ‰ RELEASES:
TypeScript 5.2 RC â€“ TS 5.2 is nearly set for its final release. Explicit resource management with using is the headline feature, but there's more, as usual.
esbuild 0.19.0 â€“ The high-perf bundler can now import paths containing wildcards and supports advanced CSS @import rules. Note that this release contains backwards-incompatible changes.
Astro 2.10 â€“ There's also a first beta of Astro 3.
Node.js Security Releases â€“ v20.5.1 (Current), v18.17.1 (LTS) and v16.20.2 (LTS) are all part of this set of releases including OpenSSL security updates and fixes, mostly, around permission policies.


ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials




  





  
  
Bringing Sharp to WebAssembly and WebContainers â€” A look at how itâ€™s possible to bring Sharp, a popular Node.js image manipulation module, into the browser. Welcome to theÂ future.
Ingvar Stepanyan 


  
  
A Compilation of Outstanding JS Testing Articles â€” An opinionated list of 10 outstanding testing articles, all with a JS slant to them. He also mentions his own list of JavaScript and Node.js Testing Best Practices which is worth revisitingÂ too.
Yoni Goldberg 


  
  
ğŸš€ JavaScript Moves Fastâ€”and So Should You. Let Us Help YouÂ Upgrade â€” React, Vue, Next, Node - our expert devs have it covered! Technical debt mounting? We're your tech debt busters!Â ğŸ‘Š
Reduce Tech Debt. UpgradeJS now. sponsor


  
  
â–¶Â Â A Look at HTMX: A 'Game-Changing' Alternative to React? â€” One of Jackâ€™s typically well produced, short tours (just 14-minutes). He likes htmx and thinks itâ€™s worth learning in order to have more options in yourÂ toolbox.
Jack Herrington 


ğŸ“ Prefer a traditional writeup? James Hibbard has one here.





  
  
Node.js's 'Config Hell' Problem â€” Andy ponders why a Next.js project has over 30 configuration files and what we can do to avoid it (unsurprisingly, it involves using Deno, but I enjoy theÂ boldness).
Andy Jiang (Deno) 


  
  
Creating a Screen + Camera Recorder with the Document Picture-in-PictureÂ API â€” This is more powerful than I was expecting. You can basically record a screencast using browser APIs. In Chrome, atÂ least.
SÃ©bastien Jalliffier Verne 


  
  
React Authentication â€” Without Complexity
Userfront sponsor


  
  
â–¶Â Â Build and Deploy a Full Stack MERN Next.js 13 Threads Clone â€” An extensive, five hour screencast walking through the creation of a Threads/Twitter/X-style app using Next.js 13 and Clerk for userÂ management.
Adrian Hajdin 


  
  
â–¶Â Â Turbopack vs Webpack â€” Being involved with the development of both bundlers, Tobias Koppers has some interesting things to say about the differences and explains why Turbopack isÂ necessary.
Tobias Koppers and Jack Herrington 


  
Autogenerating Rust-JS Bindings with UniFFI
  
Ben Dean-Kawamura (Mozilla) 
  


  
Migrating My Blog from Gatsby to Astro
  
Artem Sapegin

Moment.js

title: JavaScript Weekly
description: A newsletter of JavaScript articles, news and cool projects
